data.title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (1936)
data.meta_description: It is England in the 1830s. London's dockside is teeming with ships and sailors who have made their fortune in foreign lands. Sweeney Todd, a Fleet Street barber, awaits the arrival of men whose first port of call is for a good, close shave. For most it will be the last time they are seen alive. Using a specially designed barber's chair, Sweeney Todd despatches his victims to the cellar below, where he robs them of their new found fortunes and chops their remains into small pieces. Meanwhile, Mrs Lovett is enjoying a roaring trade for her popular penny meat pies.
data.text:
2nd George King (after The Face at the Window)

Sweeney Todd is that third iconic English folk serial killer of the 19th century, a man who killed his patrons and then sold their flesh to the pie shop next door. Todd is a fascinating figure, then, because he embodies our fear of unknowing cannibalism, the fear of revulsion at unwittingly breaking a moral taboo. A Marxist might say that he embodies the logical end of capitalism, where the working class literally feeds on one another because of the obsession with money that capitalism engenders. 19. Takes place before 1900

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

You know a film will be good when the back of the DVD is all like "Hey remember this modern film that a lot of people liked?! Yeah! This old film is based on the same source material as that one!!!"

Creepy cutter of hair mistreat child workers and chastise young maiden. Only chivalrous champion can stop his charade.

Yeah so this is a very unremarkable piece of 30s chiller. Tod Slaughter is a bit fun as the giggling maniac barber, but wow are his victims stupid.. Tod is all like "Come on in, I will cut you really good.. mwehehehehe!" And everybody is all like "Finally! A trustworthy…

I assume that the low ratings are predicated on the damage of the print as the story at large is well paced: written and enjoyable with a hint of 1930s bemusement. I think that the child actor who played Tobias was the strongest part of the production mrs Lovett is a close second and I wasn't as sold on Todd personally.

The budget must have been quite low compared to similar works of the era but it enhances a classical charm while the dialogue is far from subtle the strength here lies in its ability to not waste the viewers time and value their intelligence as I said Tobias is the best thing about this film and his subtlest nurture…
